awd_titl_txt: Developing a Combined Vibrational Spectroscopic and Optical/Fluorescence Imaging Approach for Simultaneous Orientation and Activity Measurement of Immobilized Biomolecules
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Zhan Chen of The University of Michigan is constructing an analytical platform that combines several spectroscopic and imaging analytical techniques together for the
purpose of developing a general methodology to determine the structure of surface immobilized enzymes and peptides and measure their activities simultaneously. The understanding of structure-function relationships of surface immobilized biological molecules provides
fundamental knowledge for the preparation of biocatalysts for biofuel production, biosensors, and biochips with improved performance.  An outreach program developed by Professor Chen to teach surface chemistry to high school students promotes the students' interests in science. The broader impacts of this work include developing a widely applicable analytical platform, aiding in the development of better biocatalysts, biosensors, and biochips, and educating young researchers including female
students and postdocs.

This project focuses on the development of a systematic approach by simultaneously applying linear/nonlinear vibrational spectroscopic and optical/fluorescence imaging techniques to elucidate the structure-function relationships of surface immobilized enzymes and peptides. An analytical platform which integrates sum frequency generation vibrational spectroscopy, attenuated total reflectance FTIR, optical microscopy, and fluorescence microscopy is constructed and allows for the simultaneous investigation of the structure and function of surface immobilized enzymes (e.g., beta-galactosidase and beta-glucosidase) and antimicrobial peptides
(e.g., MSI-78).

por.por_cntn:
In this research, we successfully combined several different spectroscopic and imaging techniques to build an analytical platform to study interfaces involving biological molecules. The main spectroscopic methods used are vibrational spectroscopies which can detect vibrational fingerprints of molecules at interfaces, from which we can obtain structure and behavior of said interfacial molecules. The imaging methods we employed here include fluorescence and optical imaging. Fluorescence imaging methods detect fluorescence signals from molecules after incorporation into a variety of biological systems. Using fluorescence imaging methods, we can measure the efficiency of enzymes at interfaces and evaluate whether bacteria deposited on a surface are killed or still alive. Using optical imaging, we can magnify the objects we are viewing on a surface, important to identify different non-homogeneous regions on a surface.

With the analytical platform of these combined analytical methods developed, we successfully elucidated the structure - function relationships of surface immobilized enzyme beta-Glu, an important protein in biofuel production. Our research shows that immobilizing beta-Glu enzymes by different anchoring sites on surfaces can lead to very different enzyme orientations, which further leads to varied catalytic efficiencies. By carefully choosing the surface immobilization sites, it is feasible to maximize the enzyme catalytic efficiency by optimizing the orientations of the enzymes on a surface. It was also found that enzymes immobilized on hydrophilic surfaces (surfaces attracted to water) have better efficiencies compared to those on hydrophobic surfaces (surfaces unattracted to water). In addition, using the combined spectroscopic and imaging methods, we elucidated mechanisms of surface immobilized antimicrobial peptides to kill bacteria. In the past, it was reported that many antimicrobial peptides in solution kill bacteria by aggregating on the bacteria cell membrane forming pores, destroying the bacteria cell membrane. In our study, we found that the bacteria killing mechanisms of surface immobilized antimicrobial peptides are different from that of free peptides in solution. The surface immobilized peptides lie down in the plane of the interface when interacting with bacteria. The surface immobilized peptides kill bacteria through charge interactions, rather than through pore formation. Using the combined spectroscopic/imaging approach, we also successfully studied interactions between 2-dimensional materials (2D materials - materials which can be prepared as thin films - as thin as one layer of the molecules) and peptides/proteins, including the interactions on heterogeneous 2D materials.

Surface immobilized and adsorbed peptides and proteins are widely used in many important research areas and applications such as biosensing, biochips, antimicrobial coatings, biofuel production, and biofuel cell construction. This research provides a description of structure-function relationships of peptides and proteins at interfaces that greatly helps in rational design and development of many different devices containing interfacial peptides and proteins with improved performance. Therefore, conclusions drawn from this research are important not only to the scientific community, but also society as a whole.

This research is highly interdisciplinary, covering many research fields in chemistry, physics, biology, and materials science and engineering. The postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduate students (including two female students) participated in this research received rigorous training in many different subjects, preparing them for employment in related fields in the future. Other postdocs and students in our group learned important knowledge from this project through interactions with postdocs and students who are directly involved in the research. The results obtained from this research have been published in scientific journals and presented at many conferences, institutions, as well as workshops, impacting many researchers and students inside and outside of the university, as well as the general public. The PI also incorporated important knowledge obtained from this project in his course lectures for graduate and undergraduate students, educating these students about vibrational spectroscopy, imaging, and bio-interfaces. Some of the significant results were also taught in summer surface chemistry courses designed by the PI for high school students, promoting their interests in science and engineering.
